reasoning: Crucial because the paper’s practical upshot partly hinges on whether narrow-target eutopia can nonetheless be reached via deliberate, de-dicto optimisation pressure; a strong yes/no would materially shift prioritisation between governance-building vs more politics-robust technical/containment approaches. Moderately paper-specific: it targets the paper’s explicit baseline assumption (no stronger optimisation pressure than today) and its concluding escape hatch (coordination/deliberation could still hit the target), though the institutional-design question also resembles broader AI governance debates. Tractability is middling: parts can be operationalised (comparative institutional analysis, mechanism design, historical case studies, stress-testing against capture/enforcement failures), but “reliably create and sustain” across future high-stakes contexts is difficult and likely yields only partial, model-dependent answers. Clarity is decent but still broad: what counts as ‘very best outcomes de dicto’, ‘reliably’, and acceptable failure probabilities/time horizons is underspecified. Decision hook is excellent and explicitly bifurcates strategy. Dead weight is low; the added worldview/anchor/implications mostly sharpen rather than bloat.
title: Governance mechanisms for sustained de dicto optimization amid capture
